text:

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare
at ocw.mit.edu.

GUEST SPEAKER 1: So our topic
was Holographic Particle Image

Velocimetry, also known
as HPIV for short.
So basically, what is HPIV?

And it's this really
nice technique

that allows you to
simultaneously capture

the information about
velocity vectors

in a three-dimensional
flow, which

is really hard with
conventional PIV,

because it's
two-dimensional and there's
a lot of limitations on it.

So we have some nice examples
of what you can get from HPIV.

On the top left is the near
field of a laminar jet.

And you can see that there's
velocity vectors pointing up
in the jet traction.

On the bottom we have a
turbulent flow in a square duct

and the intensity of
velocity is represented
by the different colors.
So how does HPIV do this?

Basic idea is that first you
have to record a hologram,
and then you can reconstruct it.

So when you record
your hologram,

you're interfering a
coherent reference wave

with the light that's
scattered from a particle
field of interest.

And then you're
capturing the intensity
at the plane of the hologram.

And then this is
really important,

because what you're
doing here, essentially,

is you're taking
your 3D information,

and you're storing it in
a two-dimensional form.

And then when you want to
reconstruct it and get your 3D

information back out,
you'll take your hologram,

and if you illuminate it with
the conjugate of the reference

wave, you'll give
out a real image.

And for HPIV, you
have to do this

at discrete z depths,
which we'll go into later.

So there's two basic ways that
you can illuminate your system.

The first is in line, when you
have the particle field in line
with your reference beam.

This is really nice, because
it's a relatively simple setup.

But it has some
limitations, because you

need to make sure that your
particles have a small diameter

so that they're not interfering
with the reference beam
too much.

And you can see an
image of it here.

The other main
technique is off axis.

So here you'll have like an
obliquely incident reference
beam.

There are several
advantages to this

in that you can have the real
and virtual images separate

when you're reconstructing
your images,

and you can also have much
higher seeding intensities
for your particles.

But if you're using
digital holography,

then your internet angle needs
to be less than 2 degrees,

which is pretty
tight restrictions
and makes it kind of difficult.

So when you're designing
an HPIV experiment,

there's a bunch
of considerations
that you need to worry about.

The first is recording distance,
because if your CCD is really

far away from the field
that you're studying,

then it's essentially running a
low pass filter in your system.

But if it's too
close, then you're

going to limit
your field of view,

and you may get aliasing,
which is definitely a problem.

Another consideration is the
concentration of particles.

If you have too many
particles, you'll

get a lot of speckle noise,
which is basically interference
from the different particles.

But if you don't
have enough, then you

won't really recover all of
your flow information, which
is the whole point of this.
So that's problematic.

And finally, if you're
doing digital holography,

then you need to worry
about the physical size
of your CCD and the pixel size.

So next we're going to
talk about experiment.
And that's Mike.

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
Thank you, Anna.
OK.

So here's a photograph of
our experimental setup.

We have a laser, an ND
filter, spatial filter, iris,
and collimating lens.

And the basic point of
that part of the setup

is just to get a nice
plane wave to illuminate
our area of interest.
What we're interested in--

it's a little
difficult to see here,

but there is a tiny cylinder
inside of this flow channel.

And we want to look at the
flow around that cylinder.

It's water flowing
past there seeded
with spherical particles.

And we're going to use
this camera with no lenses

to capture the
interaction between

those spherical particles
and the incoming plane wave.
OK.

So this is a
typical raw hologram

that we would get taking
images of that flow pattern.

You can see our flow
obstruction, the cylinder.

And the flow direction in our
case is from left to right.

Notice, also, that
you get the nice--

these nice diffraction
rings around the particles.

And even though this is a
2D image, we're able to--
we're able to extract that--
[AUDIO OUT]
GUEST SPEAKER 3: OK.

So as Anna mentioned,
the main use of HPIV

is to get instantaneous
3D velocity maps.

So I want to go into how
that's done in practice today.

So some of you might
be familiar with PIV.

And you might know that they
typically use image correlation
techniques.

The problem with
that is that HPIV,

since it's three-dimensional
information,
is very memory intensive.

So for example, if you take
all the reconstructed images
from our example--

it's 1 second at 500
frames per second--
it was 96 gigabytes of data.
So imagine processing that.

So instead, what people do
is use the 3D coordinates

as the data, so which is
why, as Mike described,

we need to be able to know
exactly where everything
is in 3D.

So there are two main
categories of algorithms
for creating the velocity maps.

And I want to go over an example
of each of those in a sec.

So the first one is
correlation, which
is a mostly statistical method.

And the second is
particle tracking,

which follows
individual particles

and is nicer for
more complex flows.
OK.

So here's an example of
a correlation algorithm.

Basically, what you
have is you take
two images at a time sequence.

And so the particles in
green represent maybe what

the particles look
like at time 1,
and in purple you have time 2.

So the goal is to shift
these particles around--
you can just keep clicking.

And so I should mention
that these particles--

the way you can do a
correlation on coordinates

is by representing each
particle as a Gaussian.

So then if you shift
it around until you

get the best correlation,
what you can get

is a mean displacement vector
of your particles in time.

Now, if you look at small
interrogation windows,

what you can compare from
time 1 to time 2 is--

so assuming you have
the best correlation,

you can not only compare
the minimum distance

but the change in what
people call group morphology.

So you can see, you know,
maybe due to local velocity

gradients, the particles have
shifted relative to each other
at time 2.

So, you know,
optimizing these two

things, this minimum distance
and the group morphology,

you can pair the particles
from one time step to another.

And with that, along with the
overall mean displacement,
you can get a velocity map.

So the next thing is
particle tracking.

And like I said, this is
useful in complex flows
or with lower seeding densities.

And again, you might have
a lower seeding density
to reduce speckle noise.

What you do is, in
two or more time steps

you trace numbers of
particles, and you

can fit what the most
probable or best or smoothest
velocity function is.

So you typically
have some knowledge

about what the flow
should look like.

So if you take X of i being
the location of the particles

at time X in frame i,
then you can just--

you know, you know
they might translate
through the vorticity--

I mean, sorry, transform
due to vorticity,

or there's a
translation due to flow.

And you'll get what it looks
like at the next time step Y.

So for example,
in this paper they

assigned a cost function
that looks like this.
You can click.

And if you recognize-- compare
this equation to this equation,

this is basically the
predicted position

of a set of particles
at the next time step.

So you're basically
minimizing an error,
the distance between two times.
And I'll skip the math.

Basically, these are some other
mathematically necessary terms.

So you're minimizing
this cost function.

And again, in the end you end up
with a list of particle pairs,

and you can create
velocity maps.
OK.
Yeah.

So just a few other
neat techniques

I won't go into
really great detail.
One of them was really cool.

Basically what
they do is generate

the lists of all possible
particle pairings
and call those chromosomes.

And based on a fit function
similar to the cost function

used in particle
detection, they sort of

generate parents and
offsprings, and they

keep iterating until they have
the best, most evolutionarily
fit particle pair.

And again, optical correlation,
I said, is not typically used.

But with some data
compression techniques,
some people have used them.

So in the end, what
you end up with

is a velocity map like we
showed at the beginning.

Unfortunately, our attempts
at a velocity map on ours
didn't work out.
But you could see in the video--

you could see the flow and
track the particles and whatnot.
So you get the general idea.
And so any questions?
[APPLAUSE]

AUDIENCE: So all of this
is based on the idea
that you put--

or might [INAUDIBLE] you put
particles inside the fluid.

Is there any way
that you can do this

without changing the
characteristics of a fluid

by adding particles
in, or is it solely

having these, like,
precipitates in there

and particles in there that
allows you [INAUDIBLE]..
GUEST SPEAKER 3: Yeah.
You definitely need particles.

It's holographic particle
image velocimetry.

I think, but as far as from the
fluid mechanics point of view,
small enough particles assume--
GUEST SPEAKER 1: Buoyant.

GUEST SPEAKER 3: Yeah,
neutrally buoyant particles

are assumed not to disturb the
flow, so it's not a problem.

AUDIENCE: In the papers
and the literature,

do they discuss
quantitative analysis

of the error that may be in
the experiments that they do?
They saw great velocity vectors.

Do they discuss how one
could make a ground truth
measurement?

GUEST SPEAKER 3: The air
and the velocity vector?
AUDIENCE: Mm-hmm.
GUEST SPEAKER 3: Yeah.

I mean, there were
discussions about the errors

of each step of the process, so
errors in locating particles,
errors in--
but I haven't--

I don't know if you guys
saw an in-depth-- take mic

GUEST SPEAKER 2:
Well, like she said,

they definitely talk
about the errors

in terms of the steps
of the different steps

of reconstructing,
and especially
the errors in the z dimension.

So you have-- one of the
problems with holography is you
have a depth of focus--

a depth of focus
issue, where that--

we're testing spheres
here, but it's

going to actually look kind
of like an elongated ellipse
with that extra--

with the length dimension
being in that z depth,

just as an artifact
of the reconstruction.

So there are errors
in terms of--

everyone has to make
some kind of assumption.

So you need to say, right, well,
I know that they're spherical.

So if I get an ellipse, I
can find the centroid of that
and then pick it out.

But based on your
particular program

and how you're calculating it,
you could get different errors
based on those assumptions.

GUEST SPEAKER 3: And also, one
thing-- based on the technique

that you use, there are
different trade-offs.
I don't know if this is on.

So like I said,
with correlation,

small velocity gradients-- so
maybe the eddy currents behind
the [INAUDIBLE] there--

are going to introduce errors,
because the morphology changes.

And that's kind of
detrimental to the algorithm.

So that's, you know,
depending on the technique.

I don't think you can do an
overall study [INAUDIBLE]..
AUDIENCE: OK.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
